description:
The graphic is a vertical bar chart titled “Power Conversion Efficiency of Lowest and Highest Performing Spin-coated and Spray-coated Electron Transport Layers,” shown across four centered lines at the top. The vertical axis on the left is labeled “Power conversion efficiency (%)” and runs from 0 to 18 percent. Tick labels appear at every 2-percent increment: 18 at the top down to 0 at the bottom. Horizontal grid lines span the plot at each tick (18, 16, 14, …, 0), drawn as thin black lines, with short tick marks on the left axis. The plotted region for the y-axis extends from y=120 (top, 18%) to y=320 (bottom, 0%). A thin vertical axis line is drawn at the left of the plotting area. The horizontal axis is labeled “Thickness” centered below the plot area. There are two category labels along the x-axis: “lowest performing” and “highest performing,” each placed below their respective bars and rendered diagonally (about a 40° clockwise tilt).

There are four vertical bars grouped into two side-by-side pairs. Within each pair, the left bar is light gray (#B3B3B3) and the right bar is dark gray (#333333); all bars have black outlines of similar thin thickness. The legend appears in a boxed key centered near the bottom, showing a light gray square labeled “spray coating” and a dark gray square labeled “spin coating,” indicating the color mapping.

For the “lowest performing” category, the light gray (spray coating) bar rises from the baseline to a top just below the 16% grid line, corresponding to approximately 15.5%. The adjacent dark gray (spin coating) bar reaches a top slightly below the 12% grid line, at about 11.7%. For the “highest performing” category, the light gray (spray coating) bar is the tallest overall, with its top just below the 18% line, about 17.3%. The dark gray (spin coating) bar in that category is a little below the 14% line, near 13.6%. Within each category, the spray-coating bar is taller than the spin-coating bar by roughly 3.8 percentage points in the “lowest performing” group (15.5% vs. 11.7%) and about 3.7 points in the “highest performing” group (17.3% vs. 13.6%). Comparing between categories within the same coating, the “highest performing” bars are higher by about 1.8–1.9 percentage points relative to the “lowest performing” counterparts. The bars in each pair are identical in width and touch each other; there is a gap between the two pairs roughly equal to one bar’s width. No error bars, markers, or additional annotations are present.

The figure is a vertical grouped bar chart titled “Number of Lizard Species by Average Percent of Maximal Speed Used When Pursuing Prey or Escaping Predators,” shown in three centered lines near the top. Along the bottom, the horizontal axis label reads “Percent of maximal speed.” Along the left, the vertical axis label reads “Number of lizard species.” The vertical axis runs from 0 to 9 with ticks and labels at each integer (0, 1, 2, …, 9). Thin black horizontal grid lines span the plotting area at each of these tick values, including the baseline at 0. The left vertical axis line is drawn, and the numeric tick labels are placed to the left of it.

There are seven horizontal categories, labeled along the bottom as ranges and shown rotated about 40 degrees counterclockwise: 30–39, 40–49, 50–59, 60–69, 70–79, 80–89, and 90–100. In each category there are two adjacent vertical bars: the left bar is light gray and represents “escaping,” and the right bar is dark gray and represents “pursuing.” This color coding is explained in a legend enclosed in a thin black rectangular box near the bottom center. Inside the legend, a small light-gray square with the label “escaping” appears on the left, and a small dark-gray square with the label “pursuing” appears to its right; both legend swatches have black outlines, matching the bars’ outlines. All bars are the same width, use solid fills, and have thin black borders.

Reading the bar heights from the vertical axis grid: 
- In the 30–39 category, the escaping bar is 0 (no visible height), and the pursuing bar is 1. Pursuing exceeds escaping by 1. 
- In 40–49, both escaping and pursuing are 0 (no visible bars). 
- In 50–59, escaping is 2 and pursuing is 1; escaping is higher by 1. 
- In 60–69, both are 1 (a tie). 
- In 70–79, escaping is 2 and pursuing is 0; escaping is higher by 2. 
- In 80–89, escaping is 3 and pursuing is 1; escaping is higher by 2. 
- In 90–100, escaping is 8 and pursuing is 3; escaping is higher by 5.

Across all categories, escaping bars range from 0 up to a peak of 8 (in 90–100), while pursuing bars range from 0 up to 3 (also in 90–100). Ties occur where both values are 0 (40–49) and where both are 1 (60–69). No bar reaches 9. The tallest bar overall is the escaping bar in the 90–100 category. The smallest nonzero bars are those with height 1. The overall layout has a white background, black axis and grid lines, and consistent font styling for all labels and titles.

The graphic is a line graph titled “Percentage of Maize Exported by Three Countries for Marketing Years 2009/2010–2013/2014,” centered as three stacked title lines near the top. The horizontal axis is labeled “Marketing year” beneath the plot area. The vertical axis is labeled “Percent,” rotated vertically along the left side. The vertical axis runs from 0 to 90 in increments of 10, with major tick labels at 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90. Each labeled level has a thin horizontal grid line across the full plotting width and a short tick mark intersecting the left axis. The top grid line at 90 is at y=96, and the bottom at 0 is at y=296, so the grid lines are evenly spaced. The horizontal axis shows five marketing years—2009/2010, 2010/2011, 2011/2012, 2012/2013, and 2013/2014—each with a vertical grid line extending through the plotting area and a year label set diagonally (rotated about 40 degrees) below the axis.

A legend appears in a thin black rectangular box below the plot area. It shows the three series encodings: “Argentina” is a solid black line of medium thickness (stroke width about 2.4) with small filled black triangular markers at the ends of the sample segment. “Brazil” is a black dashed line (long dash pattern, roughly 9 on/6 off) of similar thickness, with small gray square end markers outlined in black. “United States” is a black dotted line (very short dash pattern with round caps) that is slightly thicker (stroke width about 3) and has small hollow circular end markers (white fill with a thin black outline).

Within the plotting area, the three series are drawn with these styles and connect the five years left to right. Reading values from the vertical scale (where lower on the page corresponds to smaller percentages and higher toward the top corresponds to larger percentages), the solid-line series (Argentina) is near 66.5% in 2009/2010, about 66.0% in 2010/2011, rises to about 81.0% in 2011/2012, then decreases to about 70.0% in 2012/2013 and to about 65.0% in 2013/2014. The dashed-line series (Brazil) is about 21.0% in 2009/2010, about 15.0% in 2010/2011, increases to about 34.0% in 2011/2012, then declines to about 31.0% in 2012/2013 and about 27.0% in 2013/2014. The dotted-line series (United States) is about 15.0% in 2009/2010, remains at about 15.0% in 2010/2011, dips to about 13.0% in 2011/2012, reaches a low of about 7.5% in 2012/2013, and then increases to about 13.5% in 2013/2014. These values align with the 10-point grid: for example, the Argentina point at 2011/2012 sits close to the 80% grid line, while the United States point at 2012/2013 lies roughly halfway between the 0% and 10% lines.

Comparing the lines year by year, the solid line (Argentina) is the highest of the three at every year shown, peaking around 81.0% in 2011/2012 and ending around 65.0% in 2013/2014. The dashed line (Brazil) is consistently above the dotted line (United States) except in 2010/2011, where both are at about 15.0% and coincide at the same level. Differences are large between the solid line and the other two (for example, in 2011/2012 the solid line is about 47 percentage points above the dashed line and about 68 points above the dotted line), while the gap between the dashed and dotted lines ranges from about 6.0 points in 2009/2010 to about 17.5 points in 2012/2013. There are no crossings among the three series; the dashed and dotted lines meet at a single point in 2010/2011.

Visually, the plot area is bounded on the left by the vertical axis line and is overlaid with evenly spaced horizontal grid lines and vertical grid lines at each labeled year, all drawn as thin black lines. At each connection between years, the series styles include their respective small end markers, so the year positions show triangles along the solid line, squares along the dashed line, and circles along the dotted line. No shaded regions, reference bands, or additional annotations are present beyond the axes, grid, labels, and legend.

The graphic is a line graph titled “Average Monthly Rainfall in Select Puerto Rican Cities from 1981 to 2010.” The vertical axis is labeled “Average rainfall (inches)” and the horizontal axis is labeled “Month.” The months shown run from May through September. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 14 inches with tick marks and labels at every 2 inches (0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14). Horizontal grid lines span the plot at each of these labeled values. The plotting region extends from a top grid line at 14 inches down to a bottom grid line at 0 inches. A vertical axis line appears at the left edge of the plot, with short tick stubs at each labeled y value. The x-axis has five vertical guide lines at the month positions (May, June, July, August, September). The month labels are placed below the plot and are angled diagonally (rotated) so they read slanted to the right. The axis title “Month” is centered below the plot, and the y-axis title is rotated and centered along the left side.

A legend below the plot, inside a rectangular border, identifies four city series and shows their line styles and endpoint markers. Rincón is drawn with a solid black line of medium thickness (about 2.4 px) and small black triangular markers at the segment endpoints. Isabela uses a black dashed line (dash pattern of long dashes and spaces) of similar thickness and gray square markers with black outlines at the endpoints. San Sebastián uses a black dotted line (short dot–space pattern) with rounded caps, slightly thicker (about 3 px), and hollow circular markers with black outlines at the endpoints. Ponce appears in medium gray (#999) with a relatively thick solid line (about 3.5 px) and star-shaped markers (gray fill, black outline) at the endpoints. These same styles are used for the lines in the plot.

Each series shows one value per month, connected by straight line segments. Reading from the vertical scale to one decimal place, Rincón is approximately 6.3 inches in May (y ≈ 206), 5.8 in June (≈ 213.1), 6.5 in July (≈ 203.1), 8.3 in August (≈ 177.4), and 6.4 in September (≈ 204.6). Isabela is about 7.6 inches in May (≈ 187.4), 6.4 in June (≈ 204.6), 4.7 in July (≈ 228.9), 6.4 in August (≈ 204.6), and 6.1 in September (≈ 208.9). San Sebastián is about 12.9 inches in May (≈ 111.7), 11.3 in June (≈ 134.6), 7.9 in July (≈ 183.1), 10.3 in August (≈ 148.9), and 10.9 in September (≈ 140.3). Ponce is about 4.0 inches in May (≈ 238.9), 1.9 in June (≈ 268.9), 2.8 in July (≈ 256.0), 3.9 in August (≈ 240.3), and 5.9 in September (≈ 211.7).

Comparisons by month show that San Sebastián is the highest of the four in every month shown. In May it is about 12.9 inches, which is roughly 5.3 inches higher than Isabela (7.6), 6.6 inches higher than Rincón (6.3), and 8.9 inches higher than Ponce (4.0). In June it is about 11.3 inches, about 4.9 above Isabela (6.4), 5.5 above Rincón (5.8), and 9.4 above Ponce (1.9). In July it is about 7.9 inches, 1.4 above Rincón (6.5), 3.2 above Isabela (4.7), and 5.1 above Ponce (2.8). In August it is about 10.3 inches, 2.0 above Rincón (8.3), 3.9 above Isabela (6.4), and 6.4 above Ponce (3.9). In September it is about 10.9 inches, 4.5 above Rincón (6.4), 4.8 above Isabela (6.1), and 5.0 above Ponce (5.9).

Looking at each series across months, Rincón dips slightly from May to June (6.3 to 5.8), rises through July to a peak in August (8.3), and then falls to September (6.4). Isabela declines from May to a low in July (7.6 to 4.7), rebounds in August (6.4), and is slightly lower in September (6.1). San Sebastián decreases from May to a low in July (12.9 to 7.9), then increases in August and September (10.3 and 10.9). Ponce reaches its minimum in June (1.9), then increases steadily each month to a high in September (5.9). The only change in rank among the middle series occurs between June and July, where Rincón (6.5) crosses above Isabela (4.7); otherwise, Ponce remains the lowest of the four in all months, and San Sebastián remains the highest. No shaded regions or reference bands appear beyond the grid lines, and no annotations are present other than the labels and legend.

The chart’s title is “Cantaloupe Yield.” The vertical axis is labeled “Yield (pounds per acre),” and the horizontal axis is labeled “Year.” The vertical scale runs from 0 to 45 in increments of 5, with tick labels at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, and 45. Thin black horizontal grid lines span the plotting area at each of those values, and each grid line has a centered tick mark that crosses the left vertical axis line. The left axis line is drawn from the top grid line at 45 down to the baseline at 0. Year labels “2017,” “2018,” and “2019” appear below the grouped bars. A legend in a bordered box near the bottom identifies two categories: a light gray square (control) and a dark gray square (nitrogen fertilizer), both outlined in black.

Data are shown as vertical bars with black outlines (stroke width about 0.9). For each year there are two bars placed side by side, touching each other, with a noticeable gap before the next pair. The light gray bar represents “control,” and the dark gray bar represents “nitrogen fertilizer.” Approximate bar heights, read from the yield axis to one decimal place, are as follows:
- 2017: control ≈ 23.8; nitrogen fertilizer ≈ 33.8.
- 2018: control ≈ 31.6; nitrogen fertilizer ≈ 41.5.
- 2019: control ≈ 18.4; nitrogen fertilizer ≈ 27.2.

Within each year, the dark gray (nitrogen fertilizer) bar is higher than the light gray (control) bar. The difference between the two bars is about 10.0 in 2017, about 9.9 in 2018, and about 8.8 in 2019. Across years, both categories are highest in 2018 and lowest in 2019; the peaks occur in 2018 (≈ 41.5 for nitrogen fertilizer and ≈ 31.6 for control), and the smallest values occur in 2019 (≈ 27.2 for nitrogen fertilizer and ≈ 18.4 for control). The 2017 values are between the 2018 highs and the 2019 lows.

The figure is a line graph with the two-line title “California Condor Populations” on the first line and “2014–2020” on the second. The horizontal axis is labeled “Year” centered below the plot, and the vertical axis is labeled “Number of condors,” rotated vertically along the left side. The vertical axis runs from 0 to 400 in increments of 100; horizontal grid lines and matching tick labels appear at 0, 100, 200, 300, and 400. The 0 line is at the bottom of the plotting area, and the 400 line is at the top. The year axis covers 2014 through 2020 in steps of 1, with vertical grid lines aligned to each year and the year labels rotated about 40 degrees counterclockwise.

A boxed legend sits below the plot. It shows two keyed lines: a solid black line with triangular end markers labeled “captive,” and a black dashed line (long dash, short gap) with square end markers labeled “wild.” In the plot, the solid series is drawn with a continuous black stroke (approximately medium thickness) and triangle markers at the joins; the dashed series uses the same line thickness but a “9 on/6 off” dash pattern and small, light-gray-filled square markers outlined in black at the joins. Both series are drawn as straight segments between successive years.

Reading values from the vertical scale (0–400, evenly spaced), the solid “captive” line starts near 193.0 in 2014 (just below the 200 line), dips to about 167.0 in 2015, then edges up to roughly 170.0 in 2016, 173.0 in 2017, 176.0 in 2018, and 181.0 in 2019, before easing back to about 175.0 in 2020. Within this series, the lowest point is 2015 (about 167.0) and the highest is 2014 (about 193.0); from 2015 through 2019 it trends gently upward, with a small decline in 2020.

The dashed “wild” line begins near 228.0 in 2014 (a bit above the 200 line) and increases each year to about 268.0 in 2015, 276.0 in 2016, 290.0 in 2017, 312.0 in 2018, and 337.0 in 2019, then slips slightly to around 329.0 in 2020. Its lowest point is 2014 (about 228.0) and its highest is 2019 (about 337.0), followed by a modest decrease in 2020.

Across all years, the dashed “wild” series is higher than the solid “captive” series, and the two lines do not cross. The gap between them widens over time: about 35.0 in 2014 (228.0 vs. 193.0), about 101.0 in 2015 (268.0 vs. 167.0), roughly 106.0 in 2016, about 117.0 in 2017, around 136.0 in 2018, and approximately 156.0 in 2019, narrowing slightly to about 154.0 in 2020. No additional annotations, reference lines, or shaded regions appear beyond the grid lines and legend.

The figure is a vertical bar chart titled “Suggestions for Improving a University,” shown on two centered lines at the top. The vertical axis at the left is labeled “Number of suggestions” (rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise). The visible scale runs from 0 at the bottom up to 600 at the top, with tick marks and numeric labels at every 50 units: 0, 50, 100, …, 600. Thin black horizontal grid lines span the plotting area at each of these tick values. A thin black vertical axis line is drawn at the left of the plotting region, with short tick marks intersecting it at the same labeled levels.

Four vertical bars represent categories along the horizontal direction. The bars are filled light gray (#B3B3B3) with thin black outlines (stroke width about 0.9) and have equal widths. Their category labels are placed below the plotting area, diagonally (about a 40° tilt), reading from left to right: “additive,” “neither additive nor subtractive,” “subtractive,” and “invalid.” Using the grid to read heights, the approximate values are: additive ≈ 581.0 (its top is just below the 600 line, about 19 units down), neither additive nor subtractive ≈ 176.0 (between 150 and 200, closer to 200), subtractive ≈ 70.0 (between 50 and 100, closer to 50), and invalid ≈ 374.0 (between 350 and 400, closer to 400). The first and fourth bars extend well above 300, while the second is below 200 and the third is below 100.

In terms of relative sizes, additive is the tallest, invalid is second, neither additive nor subtractive is third, and subtractive is the shortest. Additive is about 207 units higher than invalid (≈581.0 vs. ≈374.0), invalid is about 198 units higher than neither additive nor subtractive (≈374.0 vs. ≈176.0), and neither additive nor subtractive is about 106 units higher than subtractive (≈176.0 vs. ≈70.0). The largest gap is between additive and subtractive, by roughly 511 units.

A small boxed legend appears near the bottom of the overall figure. Inside the box is a small gray square (matching the bar color) followed by the text “suggestion type,” indicating that the gray fill encodes the category series. There are no additional series, markers, annotations, or shaded reference regions beyond the grid lines described.

The figure title appears on two centered lines at the top: “Rotor Diameters of Newly Installed Wind” and “Turbines in the United States, 2011–2021.” The horizontal axis is labeled “Year” centered below the chart. Years from 2011 through 2021 are shown along the bottom, each printed at a -40° angle and aligned with thin vertical guide lines spanning the plotting area. The vertical axis on the left is labeled, rotated vertically, “Percent of newly installed turbines.” Horizontal grid lines and left-side tick marks are drawn at 0, 10, 20, …, 90 percent, with the labeled values “0” at the bottom (y=272) up to “90” at the top (y=72). The grid spacing is uniform at 10-percentage-point increments.

A boxed legend near the bottom shows four line styles and markers corresponding to four rotor diameter categories. “>130 meters” is a solid black line (stroke width about 2.4) with black triangular arrowheads at the ends. “<100 meters” is a black dashed line (long dashes, stroke width about 2.4) with small gray squares outlined in black at the ends. “100–115 meters” is a black dotted line (short dot–space pattern, round line caps, stroke width about 3) with white circular markers outlined in black at the ends. “115–130 meters” is a medium-gray line (stroke width about 3.5) with small eight-pointed star-shaped markers (gray fill, black outline) at the ends.

Within the plot, each category is drawn as connected segments from year to year using the corresponding style. Reading values from the vertical scale (0 at the bottom, 90 at the top), the “<100 meters” dashed line starts high and declines: about 78.0% in 2011, 53.0% in 2012, 26.0% in 2013, 20.0% in 2014, 14.0% in 2015, 3.0% in 2016, then about 1.0% in both 2017 and 2018, and effectively 0.0% in 2019, 2020, and 2021. The “100–115 meters” dotted line rises into the midrange before falling: about 22.0% (2011), 47.0% (2012), 74.0% (2013), 80.0% (2014), 79.0% (2015), 70.0% (2016), 60.0% (2017), 43.0% (2018), 16.0% (2019), 9.0% (2020), and 11.0% (2021). The “115–130 meters” gray line begins near zero and then increases into the upper range: about 0.0% in 2011–2013, 1.0% in 2014, 7.0% in 2015, 27.0% in 2016, 39.0% in 2017, 53.0% in 2018, peaking around 69.0% in 2019 and 74.0% in 2020, then easing to 66.0% in 2021. The “>130 meters” solid black line stays at 0.0% from 2011 through 2017, then rises to about 3.0% (2018), 15.0% (2019), 17.0% (2020), and 23.0% (2021).

Comparisons at specific years show clear shifts among the categories. In 2011, “<100 meters” (78.0%) is higher than “100–115 meters” (22.0%) by about 56 percentage points, while the two larger-diameter categories are at 0.0%. By 2013, “100–115 meters” (74.0%) exceeds “<100 meters” (26.0%) by about 48 points. “115–130 meters” remains near zero through 2014 but grows steadily thereafter, surpassing “<100 meters” between 2015 (7.0% vs 14.0%) and 2016 (27.0% vs 3.0%), and exceeding “100–115 meters” between 2017 (39.0% vs 60.0%) and 2018 (53.0% vs 43.0%). The “>130 meters” line remains at 0.0% through 2017, then climbs; by 2020 it is above “100–115 meters” (17.0% vs 9.0%), and by 2021 it reaches 23.0% while “115–130 meters” is 66.0% and “100–115 meters” is 11.0%. Throughout 2019–2021, “<100 meters” is at or near 0.0%. The category lines often overlap at the 0% baseline in the early years for “>130 meters” and “115–130 meters” and in the later years for “<100 meters,” while the midrange and larger categories separate clearly with upward or downward slopes consistent with the values noted.

The figure is a vertical bar chart titled, on two centered lines at the top, “Top Four Species of Wild Land” and “Mammals by Global Biomass.” The vertical axis at the left is labeled, rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise, “Global biomass (millions of metric tons).” Along this axis, horizontal grid lines and tick marks appear at regular 0.5-unit intervals from 0 up to 3.0, with numeric labels 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, and 3.0 printed to the left of the axis. The zero line is the bottom grid line, and the 3.0 line is at the top of the plotted area. A solid vertical axis line runs up the left side of the plot; each tick has a short leftward tick mark, and each tick level is extended across the plotting area as a light horizontal line.

There are four vertical bars, evenly spaced from left to right, each filled a medium gray (#B3B3B3) with a thin black outline of consistent thickness. Each bar represents a category labeled beneath it by a black text label rotated about 40 degrees counterclockwise and aligned so the text ends near the bar’s base. From left to right, the labels read: “African bush elephant,” “eastern gray kangaroo,” “wild boar,” and “white-tailed deer.” A small legend sits near the bottom center of the figure inside a thin black-outlined rectangle; within it a small gray square (matching the bar color) appears to the left of the word “species,” indicating that the gray fill encodes the species categories.

Reading the bar heights against the vertical scale:
- African bush elephant rises to about 1.3 million metric tons.
- eastern gray kangaroo rises to about 0.6 million metric tons.
- wild boar rises to about 1.9 million metric tons.
- white-tailed deer rises to about 2.7 million metric tons.

Comparing values, white-tailed deer is the tallest bar (about 2.7), higher than wild boar by roughly 0.8, higher than African bush elephant by roughly 1.4, and higher than eastern gray kangaroo by roughly 2.1. Wild boar (about 1.9) is taller than African bush elephant by about 0.6 and taller than eastern gray kangaroo by about 1.3. African bush elephant (about 1.3) is taller than eastern gray kangaroo by about 0.7. No bars reach the top of the scale (3.0), and all values are well above 0. The plot contains no additional annotations, reference lines, or shaded regions beyond the grid lines and labels described.

The figure is a two-line title centered at the top reading “Copper Production for” on the first line and “Three States, 1889-1909” on the second. The vertical axis at the left is labeled, reading from bottom to top along the left margin: “Yearly copper production” and, on a second line, “(in millions of pounds).” The horizontal axis is labeled “Year” centered below the plotting area.

The vertical scale runs from 0 to 400, with major horizontal grid lines and tick labels at 0, 100, 200, 300, and 400. These grid lines are thin, solid black lines extending across the plot from the left axis (x≈113.8) to the right edge of the plotting area (x≈365). Corresponding tick labels appear just to the left of the axis: “0” at the bottom grid line (y=272), “100” (y=222), “200” (y=172), “300” (y=122), and “400” (y=72). Short tick marks protrude to the left of the axis at each of these levels. The x-axis uses three vertical reference lines spanning the plotting height at the specific years 1889 (x≈155.7), 1902 (x≈239.4), and 1909 (x≈323.1); each of these has a centered tick label below the axis: “1889,” “1902,” and “1909.”

There are three data series, each plotted as straight line segments connecting the three year positions and distinguished by line style and endpoint markers, as also shown in a legend. The legend is a rectangular box with a black outline and no fill placed below the plot. Inside it, three samples are labeled to the right: “Montana” corresponds to a solid black line of medium thickness (about 2.4 px) with small solid black triangular markers at the endpoints; “Arizona” corresponds to a black dashed line (long dashes, roughly 9 px, with 6 px gaps) of similar thickness and gray square markers with black outlines at the endpoints; “Michigan” corresponds to a dotted line (very short dash pattern, round-capped, drawn at a slightly heavier weight, about 3 px) with white circular markers outlined in black at the endpoints. These same styles appear on the plotted data, with markers visible at each plotted year.

Using the vertical grid for approximate values (each 50 px step equals 100 units; 1 px ≈ 2 units), the solid-line series (Montana) is at about 104.0 in 1889 (y≈220), rises to about 266.0 in 1902 (y≈139), and further to about 314.0 in 1909 (y≈115). The dashed-line series (Arizona) is lowest at about 32.0 in 1889 (y≈256), increases to about 119.0 in 1902 (y≈212.5), and then increases sharply to about 291.0 in 1909 (y≈126.5). The dotted-line series (Michigan) starts near about 87.0 in 1889 (y≈228.5), rises to about 170.0 in 1902 (y≈187), and reaches about 231.0 in 1909 (y≈156.5).

At the earliest year, the ordering is Montana highest (~104.0), then Michigan (~87.0), then Arizona (~32.0). By 1902, the same order holds with wider separations: Montana (~266.0) is about 96.0 higher than Michigan (~170.0) and about 147.0 higher than Arizona (~119.0); Michigan is about 51.0 higher than Arizona. By 1909, Montana remains highest at about 314.0, Arizona has risen to about 291.0, and Michigan is at about 231.0; Montana exceeds Arizona by about 23.0 and exceeds Michigan by about 83.0, while Arizona exceeds Michigan by about 60.0. All three series increase from 1889 to 1909, with Montana’s largest jump occurring from 1889 to 1902 (~+162.0) and Arizona’s largest jump occurring from 1902 to 1909 (~+172.0). The Arizona and Michigan lines switch order between 1902 and 1909, implying a crossing between those years; Montana remains above both at all plotted years. There are no shaded regions or additional annotations beyond the grid lines, axis labels, and legend.

The graphic is a line graph titled “Ratio of Manganese to Calcium in Samples from Alboran Sea and Mauritanian Coast,” shown across two centered title lines at the top. The vertical axis on the left is labeled “Manganese to calcium ratio” with the unit “(micromoles per mole),” and the horizontal axis below the plot is labeled “Approximate years before present” with “(in thousands)” on a second line. The vertical scale runs from 0 at the bottom to 100 at the top in increments of 10, with horizontal grid lines and left-side tick labels at 0, 10, 20, …, 100. The horizontal scale shows ticks and vertical grid lines at 2, 4, 6, …, 20 (thousands of years). A vertical baseline is drawn at the left edge of the plot area, and the grid consists of evenly spaced black lines at each labeled interval in both directions.

A legend appears in a bordered rectangle below the chart area, centered horizontally. It contains two line samples and labels. The first sample is a solid black line segment (stroke thickness about 2.4) with triangular arrowheads at both ends; it is labeled “Alboran Sea.” The second sample is a dashed black line segment (dash pattern long-short, approximately 9 on/6 off, same thickness) with small square caps at both ends (light gray fill with black outline); it is labeled “Mauritanian coast.”

Two series are plotted across the grid at the x-values 2, 4, 6, …, 20. The Alboran Sea series is drawn as solid black segments linking each successive point, with triangular arrowheads at each segment’s ends. Reading approximate values from the vertical axis:
- At 2: about 63.2 micromoles per mole.
- At 4: about 99.5.

A boxed legend sits below the plot area, roughly centered, containing four sample line segments with their styles and labels. The series encodings are:
- Algeria: a solid black line (stroke width about 2.4) with small solid black triangular markers at segment ends.
- France: a black dashed line (long dashes, dash pattern about 9 on/6 off, stroke width about 2.4) with gray square markers outlined in black at segment ends.
- Japan: a black dotted line (very short dash pattern about 1.1 on/6 off with round caps, stroke width about 3) with white circular markers outlined in black at segment ends.
- Nigeria: a thicker medium-gray line (#999, stroke width about 3.5) with small gray star-like markers outlined in black at segment ends.

Four lines span 1970 to 2020, with one data point each decade. Reading values from the vertical axis (0–100%), the approximate percentages for each decade are as follows. In 1970: Japan about 76.9%, France about 71.1%, Algeria about 39.5%, and Nigeria about 17.8%. In 1980: Japan about 80.2%, France about 73.3%, Algeria about 43.5%, Nigeria about 22.0%. In 1990: Japan about 84.3%, France about 74.1%, Algeria about 52.1%, Nigeria about 29.7%. In 2000: Japan about 87.6%, France about 75.9%, Algeria about 59.9%, Nigeria about 34.8%. In 2010: Japan about 90.8%, France about 78.4%, Algeria about 67.5%, Nigeria about 43.5%. In 2020: Japan about 91.5%, France about 79.0%, Algeria about 73.7%, Nigeria about 52.0%. The plotted lines are smooth, monotonic decade-to-decade increases for all four series, with no reversals within the decades shown.

Across all years shown, Japan’s line is highest, followed by France, then Algeria, then Nigeria; there are no crossings. The gaps between series vary by decade. For example, in 1970 Japan is about 5.8 percentage points above France (76.9% vs. 71.1%); by 2020 that difference is about 12.5 points (91.5% vs. 79.0%). France exceeds Algeria by about 31.6 points in 1970 (71.1% vs. 39.5%) and by about 5.3 points in 2020 (79.0% vs. 73.7%). Algeria exceeds Nigeria by roughly 21.7 points in 1970 (39.5% vs. 17.8%) and also by about 21.7 points in 2020 (73.7% vs. 52.0%). Decade-to-decade increases are modest for France (roughly +0.6 to +2.5 points per decade) and Japan (roughly +0.7 to +4.1), and larger for Algeria and Nigeria at various intervals (Algeria grows by about +4.0 to +8.6 points per decade; Nigeria by about +4.2 to +8.7). There are no annotations, reference lines, or shaded regions beyond the grid.

The figure is a line graph titled “Recreation Visits by Month to Four US National Parks during the Peak Season in 2021.” The horizontal axis is labeled “Month,” and the vertical axis is labeled “Number of recreation visits (in thousands of visitors).” The vertical scale runs from 0 to 1,100, marked every 100 (0, 100, 200, …, 1,100). Thin horizontal grid lines span the plotting area at each 100-unit tick, from y=346 (0) up to y=96 (1,100). The vertical plotting boundary at the left is a thin line at x≈118.6. Three thin vertical guide lines mark the months at x≈159.7, 241.8, and 323.9, with the tick labels “June,” “July,” and “August,” respectively, placed below and rotated about 40 degrees counterclockwise. The axis label “Month” appears centered below the chart.

A legend appears in a rectangular box below the plot. It shows four line styles with their labels to the right. “Yellowstone” is encoded by a solid black line (stroke width about 2.4) with small black triangular markers at the data points. “Zion” is a black dashed line (dash pattern long dashes, stroke width about 2.4) with square markers (light gray fill with black outline). “Grand Canyon” is a black dotted line (very short dashes with round caps, stroke width about 3) with white circular markers outlined in black. “Rocky Mountain” is a medium-gray line (stroke color #999, thicker at about 3.5) with star/diamond-shaped markers (gray fill, black outline).

Each series has two connecting segments, from June to July and from July to August, with the markers appearing at the three month positions. Reading from the vertical scale (in thousands of visitors):
- Yellowstone: June is at about 939; July rises to about 1,081; August falls to about 922. Thus, it increases by about 142 from June to July, then decreases by about 159 from July to August.
- Zion: June is about 676; July is about 581; August is about 467. This declines by about 95 from June to July and by about 114 from July to August, a steady month-by-month decrease.
- Grand Canyon: June is about 539; July rises slightly to about 557; August drops to about 431. That is an increase of about 18 from June to July, then a decrease of about 126 from July to August.
- Rocky Mountain: June is about 671; July jumps to about 905; August eases to about 746. That is an increase of about 234 from June to July, followed by a decrease of about 159 from July to August.

Comparing parks within each month, Yellowstone is highest each month: about 939 in June (top among the four), about 1,081 in July (near the top of the chart, between the 1,000 and 1,100 grid lines), and about 922 in August. In June, Zion (about 676) is slightly above Rocky Mountain (about 671) by around 5, and both exceed Grand Canyon (about 539) by roughly 132 and 137, respectively. In July, Yellowstone (about 1,081) leads Rocky Mountain (about 905) by about 176; Zion (about 581) is above Grand Canyon (about 557) by about 24. In August, Yellowstone (about 922) is again highest, ahead of Rocky Mountain (about 746) by about 176; Zion (about 467) remains above Grand Canyon (about 431) by about 36. No series cross one another over the three months; Zion remains above Grand Canyon in all three, and Rocky Mountain remains below Yellowstone but above Grand Canyon throughout, overtaking Zion after June. There are no shaded regions or additional annotations beyond the axes, grid lines, and legend.

The figure is a monochrome line graph titled “Average Survival of Fruit Flies” on the first line and “following Infection” on the second. The vertical axis on the left is labeled “Survival rate (% alive).” Its scale runs from 110 at the top down to 0 at the bottom, marked every 10 units with labels 110, 100, 90, 80, 70, 60, 50, 40, 30, 20, 10, and 0. Thin horizontal grid lines extend across the plotting area at each of these labeled levels, and a vertical axis line runs up the left side. At each vertical tick (0, 2, 6, 10, 14 days), a thin vertical grid line spans the height of the plot.

Three series are shown and identified in a legend enclosed in a thin rectangular box beneath the plot. In the legend, “type A flies” is depicted by a solid black line of moderate thickness with small black triangular markers at the segment ends; “type AB flies” is depicted by a black dashed line (long dash pattern) of similar thickness with small gray-filled squares (black-outlined) at the segment ends; and “type B flies” is depicted by a black dotted line (widely spaced short dots; round end caps) that is slightly thicker, with small open circles (white fill, black outline) at the segment ends. These same encodings appear on the plotted lines, with the small markers at each segment endpoint.

All three series share the same starting point at day 0, at the horizontal grid line labeled 100, so each begins at about 100.0% survival. From day 0 to day 2, the solid type A line remains essentially flat at the 100% line (about 100.0% at both 0 and 2 days). Over the subsequent intervals, it declines gently: at day 6 it is at a y-level 0.4 of a tick below the 100% line (about 96.0%), at day 10 it is 0.8 of a tick below 100% (about 92.0%), and by day 14 it reaches the 90% grid line (about 90.0%). This line appears nearly horizontal at first and then slopes downward slightly at each labeled day, remaining the highest of the three series at every time point.

The dashed type AB line starts at the same 100.0% at day 0, is a little lower by day 2 at roughly 98.0% (about 0.2 of a tick below 100), and then drops steeply thereafter. At day 6 it is between the 50% and 40% grid lines, 0.4 of a tick below the 50% line (about 46.0%). By day 10 it is just above the 10% line by 0.2 of a tick (about 12.0%). At day 14 it reaches the bottom axis at the 0% line (about 0.0%). The dotted type B line also begins at 100.0% at day 0, but is lower than type AB by day 2 at about 96.0% (0.4 of a tick below 100). It continues to trend lower than type AB at the later times: at day 6 it sits just 0.1 of a tick above the 40% line (about 41.0%), at day 10 it is 0.4 of a tick above the 0% line (about 4.0%), and at day 14 it also reaches 0.0%. Thus, at day 2 the ordering is type A ≈ 100.0%, type AB ≈ 98.0%, type B ≈ 96.0% (about 2.0 percentage points between adjacent series). At day 6, type A ≈ 96.0% is higher than type AB ≈ 46.0% by about 50.0 points, and type AB exceeds type B ≈ 41.0% by about 5.0 points. At day 10, type A ≈ 92.0% exceeds type AB ≈ 12.0% by about 80.0 points, and type AB exceeds type B ≈ 4.0% by about 8.0 points. At day 14, type A remains at about 90.0%, while both type AB and type B are at about 0.0%. No lines cross one another at the labeled days; type A is highest throughout, type AB remains above type B after day 0, and the two lower series converge to the x-axis by the final tick. There are no shaded regions or additional annotations beyond the grid, axes, labels, and legend.

For processing with inputs, the bars are intermediate in height: 2000 is 650.0, 2003 is 1,250.0, and 2006 is 2,300.0; increases are 600.0 from 2000 to 2003 and 1,050.0 from 2003 to 2006 (1,650.0 from 2000 to 2006).

Comparing categories within each year, ordinary imports are the tallest in all three years, followed by processing with inputs, then processing with assembly. In 2000, ordinary imports exceed processing with inputs by 350.0 and processing with assembly by 750.0; in 2003, ordinary imports exceed processing with inputs by 450.0 and processing with assembly by 1,350.0; in 2006, ordinary imports exceed processing with inputs by 1,000.0 and processing with assembly by 2,550.0. The highest bar overall is ordinary imports in 2006 at 3,300.0, and the lowest is processing with assembly in 2000 at 250.0. All three categories show increases from 2000 to 2003 to 2006.

The graphic is a line chart titled “Singer Sewing Machine Sales in Four Countries, 1903–1918,” shown on two centered lines at the top. The horizontal axis is labeled “Year” centered below the plotting area, with four tick marks labeled 1903, 1908, 1913, and 1918; these year labels are angled diagonally downward to the right. Vertical reference lines run the full plot height at each of those four years. The vertical axis at the left is labeled “Machines sold” (rotated vertically) and is numbered from 0 to 60,000 in steps of 10,000. Horizontal grid lines span the plot at 0; 10,000; 20,000; 30,000; 40,000; 50,000; and 60,000, with the top line at 60,000 and the bottom line at 0.

Four series are plotted across the four years, each drawn as a line with a distinct style and endpoint markers, and also shown in a boxed legend below the chart. New Zealand is a solid black line of medium thickness with small black triangular markers; Australia is a black dashed line (long dashes) of the same thickness with small gray square markers outlined in black; the Philippines is a black line with widely spaced dot-like segments (very short dash pattern with rounded caps), slightly thicker than the previous two, with small white circular markers outlined in black; Turkey is a thicker gray line with small eight-pointed star markers outlined in black. The legend box appears below the plot and pairs each line sample and marker style with its country name in this order: New Zealand, Australia, the Philippines, Turkey.

Reading approximate values from the vertical scale (0 at the bottom to 60,000 at the top), New Zealand stays near 4–5 thousand throughout: about 4,284.0 in 1903, 4,918.0 in 1908, 4,962.0 in 1913, and 4,119.0 in 1918. Australia is roughly in the low-to-mid 20 thousands early and dips by 1918: about 21,147.0 in 1903, 24,276.0 in 1908, 24,495.0 in 1913, and 20,332.0 in 1918. The Philippines starts the lowest and rises sharply: about 1,937.0 in 1903, 2,241.0 in 1908, then up to 27,266.0 in 1913 and 44,820.0 in 1918. Turkey rises strongly to a high in 1913 and then falls steeply: about 24,439.0 in 1903, 33,200.0 in 1908, 50,794.0 in 1913, and 13,604.0 in 1918.

Comparisons at each year show the ordering and differences clearly. In 1903, Turkey (24,439.0) is higher than Australia (21,147.0) by about 3,292.0, both far above New Zealand (4,284.0) and the Philippines (1,937.0). In 1908, Turkey (33,200.0) leads Australia (24,276.0) by about 8,924.0; New Zealand (4,918.0) exceeds the Philippines (2,241.0) by about 2,677.0. By 1913, Turkey peaks at 50,794.0; the Philippines (27,266.0) has surged past Australia (24,495.0) by about 2,771.0, while New Zealand (4,962.0) remains much lower. In 1918, the Philippines is highest at 44,820.0, about 24,488.0 above Australia (20,332.0); Turkey has dropped to 13,604.0 and New Zealand is lowest at 4,119.0. Between intervals, notable changes include the Philippines’ large increases of about +25,025.0 from 1908 to 1913 and +17,554.0 from 1913 to 1918; Turkey’s rise of about +17,594.0 from 1908 to 1913 followed by a sharp decrease of about −37,190.0 to 1918; Australia’s small rise (+219.0) from 1908 to 1913 and then decline (−4,163.0) to 1918; and New Zealand’s modest rise (+634.0) to 1908, slight further increase (+44.0) to 1913, and decrease (−843.0) to 1918. Crossovers implied by these trajectories include the Philippines moving above Australia between 1908 and 1913, and Turkey moving from above Australia in 1913 to below it by 1918; the Philippines also overtakes Turkey between 1913 and 1918.

A legend in a bordered box below the plot identifies four line styles and labels, top to bottom: “females with saline,” “males with saline,” “males with CNO,” and “females with CNO.” “Females with saline” is a solid black line (stroke about 2.4 px) with small black triangular markers at the segment ends. “Males with saline” is a black dashed line (long dashes, about 9 on/6 off, stroke about 2.4 px) with small gray square markers edged in black. “Males with CNO” is a fine black dotted line (short dash pattern, round caps, stroke about 3 px) with small hollow circular markers. “Females with CNO” is a thicker medium‑gray line (stroke about 3.5 px) with eight‑pointed star‑like gray markers outlined in black. Visually, “females with CNO” is consistently the highest of the four series after time 10, rising sharply to about 1,400.0 at 38 minutes and then declining but remaining above the other series through 136 minutes; by 150 minutes it is still higher than the others at roughly 350.0. “Males with CNO” stays moderate, between about 450.0–600.0 through 108 minutes, then drops to about 235.0 at 122 minutes and ends near 205.0 at 150 minutes. “Females with saline” varies widely, dipping to a low near 75.0 at 52 minutes, showing brief plateaus around 175.0 between 94 and 108 minutes, and finishing at about 200.0. “Males with saline” is generally the lowest, reaching a minimum near 65.0 at 94 minutes, rising to about 225.0 at 122 minutes, and ending at 200.0. For the dwarf honeybee, the 5-sided bar is highest at about 2.6, the 7-sided bar is about 2.1, and the 8-sided bar is about 0.2; here the 5-sided bar exceeds the 7-sided by about 0.5 point, and the 8-sided bar is 1.9 points below the 7-sided and 2.4 points below the 5-sided. Comparing across species by shape: for 5-sided cells, dwarf honeybee (≈2.6) is slightly higher than black dwarf honeybee (≈2.5) by about 0.1 point, and both are much higher than western honeybee (≈0.5) by about 2.0–2.1 points. For 7-sided cells, black dwarf honeybee (≈2.4) is higher than dwarf honeybee (≈2.1) by about 0.3 point, and both exceed western honeybee (≈0.4) by about 1.7–2.0 points. For 8-sided cells, dwarf honeybee (≈0.2) is highest, western honeybee (≈0.1) is next, and black dwarf honeybee is at 0.0; the differences are small (about 0.1–0.2 point).
